xxl.core.collections.queues
Class AbstractQueue<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.queues.AbstractQueue<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements of this queue.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Queue<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
ArrayQueue, FileStackQueue, Heap, ListQueue, StackQueue, StreamQueue
public abstract class AbstractQueue<E>
extends Object
implements Queue<E>

This class provides a skeletal implementation of the Queue interface, to minimize the effort required to implement this interface.

To implement a queue, the programmer only needs to extend this class and provide implementations for the methods dequeueObject, enqueueObject and peekObject.

The documentation for each non-abstract method in this class describes its implementation in detail. Each of these methods may be overridden if the queue being implemented admits a more efficient implementation.

See Also:
Queue

Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the queue, i.e., signals the queue to reserve resources, open files, etc.
Before a queue has been opened calls to methods like peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a queue's data can be processed.
Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the queue remains in the state opened until its close method is called.
Note that a call to the open method of a closed queue usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Queue<E>

close

public void close()
Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it (like closing files, cleaning up resources, etc.).
This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method take the same effect as a single call (which means that if close was called the queue remains in the state closed).
Note: This method is very important for queues using external resources like files or JDBC resources.
This implementation is given by an empty body.

Specified by:
close in interface Queue<E>

enqueue

public final void enqueue(E object)
                   throws IllegalStateException
Appends the specified element to the end of this queue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy.
This method calls enqueueObject(Object object) which has to implement the store procedure (depending on the strategy and the underlying datastructure).

Specified by:
enqueue in interface Queue<E>
Parameters:
object - element to be appended to the end of this queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the queue is already closed when this method is called.

enqueueObject

protected abstract void enqueueObject(E object)
Abstract method which has to be overwritten by any class extending this class.
This method is invoked by enque(Object object) and has to implement the store procedure depending on the strategy and the used datastructure.

Parameters:
object - element to be appended to the end of this queue.

peek

public final E peek()
             throws IllegalStateException,
                    NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the queue without removing it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.
After calling peek the returned element is still the queue's next one such that a call to dequeue and then peek would be the only way to access the next element.
This method internally calls peekObject which actually implements the operation.

Specified by:
peek in interface Queue<E>
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the queue is closed.
NoSuchElementException - if queue has no more elements.

peekObject

protected abstract E peekObject()
Returns the next element in the queue without removing it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.
This method is invoked by peek and has to implement the peek procedure depending on the strategy and the used datastructure.

Returns:
the next element in the queue.

dequeue

public final E dequeue()
                throws IllegalStateException,
                       NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the queue and removes it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy. This method internally calls dequeueObject which actually implements the operation.

Specified by:
dequeue in interface Queue<E>
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the queue is already closed when this method is called.
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

dequeueObject

protected abstract E dequeueObject()
Returns the next element in the queue (and removes it). The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.
This method is invoked by dequeue and has to implement the peek procedure depending on the strategy and the used datastructure.

Returns:
the next element in the queue.

isEmpty

public final boolean isEmpty()
Returns false if the queue has more elements. (In other words, returns false if peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
isEmpty in interface Queue<E>
Returns:
false if the queue has more elements.

size

public final int size()
Returns the number of elements in this queue. If this queue contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, Integer.MAX_VALUE is returned.

Specified by:
size in interface Queue<E>
Returns:
the number of elements in this queue.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
Note that the elements will only be removed from the queue but not from the underlying collection.
This implementation iterates over this queue, calling the dequeue method for every element, in turn.

Specified by:
clear in interface Queue<E>
